item.title: Comment on Tuesday assorted links by Crusader
item.description:
5. As I’ve commented before, the lost fares are nothing compared to the real cost:

The people who follow the rules growing resentful and feeling that there’s no point in adhering to the social contract anymore. This is really what’s holding up society and once this collapses it’s over.

I have no issue with paying the $2.75 for the MTA when I’m in NYC. But when I see other people not pay it (even in front of NYPD officers who do nothing), I feel like “why the hell am I paying for it?” It really poisons your willingness to pay taxes and fees to support the Government, which should be something we feel decent about doing.

I feel like an important political thing is that the middle class and “normal, good people who do their best” need to have a huge premium placed to their QOL and how they feel. Letting a small number of “bad people” hurt this population, whether it’s explicit crime or even someone yelling threats and causing issues in the subway, is a massive aggregate QOL drag and it’s not fair to subject “normal good people” to it IMO.

On a tangential note, I wish the progressives would stop making the demonization of the wealthy a core part of the platform. I’m sure Elon and Bezos and others are happy to pay taxes to a society that uses the money productively and is as appreciative back as Elon and Bezos are to the US and the people that make it all possible.

item.title: Comment on Obama’s space legacy? by Ricardo
item.description:
This is all accurate and even common knowledge among people who have been following space news. But there is the opening sentence: "Bucking his central planning instincts, Obama embraced a surprisingly laissez-faire approach to space flight that angered political allies and opponents alike."

Obama accomplished this so early in his presidency that anyone who thought Obama was hostile toward markets and had "central planning instincts" was not basing that impression on any actual evidence.

That said, the policy still was not "laissez-faire." It was part privatization, part government-sponsored R&D because NASA paid SpaceX upfront in order to fund and subsidize their development of heavy lift rockets and crew capsules. SpaceX pays back NASA over time with launches. It is highly unlikely any private VCs or telecom companies would have given SpaceX funding on the same generous terms.
